Duration: 2 years (4 semesters)

International Tuition: $17,417.00 **
Location: Waterfront Campus
Program Availability:
- Semester 1, 3: Hybrid (Fall 2023)
- Semester 2, 4: Hybrid (Winter 2024)
Related Programs: Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate) (C405), Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (S302), Practical Nursing (PN) (S121)
Program Description: Preparing students to work in the field of behavioural science for more than 15 years. All full-time program faculty are Board-Certified Behaviour Analysts (BCBAs).

Context:
The Behavioural Science Technician program at the college focuses on teaching behavioural principles, assessment and intervention procedures, and professional skills for employment in various workplaces such as autism, mental health, gerontology, acquired brain injury, organizational behaviour management, sport, etc. This program does not teach counselling or "talk therapy" skills. The themes studied in this program include behavioural theory, behavioural assessment, behavioural acquisition and reduction strategies, scientific method, ethics and professionalism, and general education with a practical application in the field. Students can find employment opportunities as behaviour science technicians upon completion of the program. For those with a bachelor's degree in psychology or related discipline, an accelerated delivery of this program leading to a diploma is offered in less than one year.

Associations related to this field of study include the Association of Behaviour Analysis International, The Ontario Association for Behaviour Analysis, Inc., and Association of Professional Behavior Analysts. Students can also visit the Behavior Analyst Certification Board for more information on this field of study.

The field placement component of the program provides students with the opportunity to apply theoretical knowledge in a real-world environment. Each field experience builds upon the previous one and provides exposure to various work environments. Field placements are unpaid and completed on a full-time basis, and George Brown Faculty works with students and community partners to secure these placements. Field education may require travel due to the availability of suitable placements within the Greater Toronto Area (GTA), potentially extending as far east as Oshawa and as far west as an undisclosed location.

No specific years, numbers, emails, or names were provided in the text.

Context:
The Behavioural Science Technician program offered at George Brown College is a two-year Ontario College diploma program with the code C146. Graduates of this program are eligible to enter the bridging pathway into the third year of the Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis degree program (S303). International students who have completed this program can apply to the S303 Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis (Year 3 Bridge) program stream.

Career options for Behavioural Science Technician graduates include being an instructor therapist, behaviour therapist, behaviour technician, behaviour consultant, resource facilitator, or working in residential facilities, vocational agencies, or other specialized agencies.

The first semester courses for this program include Behavioural Theory (BST 1003), Behaviour Theory and Practice: Introduction to ABA (BST 1007), Lifespan Development (BST 1021), Introduction to Psychology (BST 1022), Strategies for Student Success (BST 1028), College Communication (COMM 1000 or COMM 2000), and a General Education Elective.

The second semester courses are Developmental Disabilities in Ontario: Policy and Process (BST 1029), Behaviour Theory and Practice: Behavioural Assessment (BST 1030), Interpersonal and Group Skills (BST 1031), Ethics and Professionalism (BST 1032), and Field Seminar I (BST 2009).

For more information about the degree pathway or international student applications, please contact Program Co-ordinator Don Togade at Don.Togade@georgebrown.ca. Graduates interested in working in a long-term care facility should consider applying to the Interprofessional Complex and Long-Term Care postgraduate certificate (S417).

Context:
The text provides information about various courses offered in Semesters 3 and 4 of a Behaviour Science Technician (BST) program at the college. Here are the factual information and entities extracted from the text:

1. Courses: BST 1032, Ethics and Professionalism; BST 2009, Field Seminar I; BST 2014, Field Placement I; BST 2035, Research Design and Statistics; BST 2036, Behaviour Theory and Practice: Acquisition Strategies; BST 2037, Behaviour Theory and Practice: Reduction Strategies; BST 2027, Field Seminar II; BST 2038, Field Placement II; PSY 2017, Abnormal Psychology; BST 2039, Special Populations: Childhood Issues; BST 2040, Special Populations: Acquired Brain Injury and Gerontology; BST 2041, Behaviour Theory and Practice: Group-Based Interventions; BST 2042, Field Seminar III; BST 2043, Field Placement III.
2. Semesters: Semester 3 and Semester 4.
3. Required course before progressing to COMM 2000 (if necessary): COMM 1000, Introduction to College Communication.
4. Graduate abilities: Implement effective behaviour analytic intervention strategies based on the science of Applied Behaviour Analysis (ABA); integrate background information and knowledge of special populations into therapeutic practice; communicate with various stakeholders the behaviour analytic principles, processes and concepts central to interventions; compile measurements of behaviour in accordance with ONTABA standards and BACB Guidelines; apply systems thinking to behavioural processes related to socially significant behaviour change; adhere to federal, provincial, and professional policies and regulations associated with ethical practice of ABA; develop effective client service intervention based on collaboration with stakeholders and professionals.
5. Important note: Students may be required to take COMM 1000 before progressing to COMM 2000. This course does not count towards graduation requirements but will incur additional charges. Students are advised to visit the Assessment Centre for more information.

Context:
The text provides information about admission requirements for applicants to certain programs at George Brown College. Here are some key facts extracted from the text:

1. Applicants may need to take an Admissions Assessment in English or upgrade their English skills to meet program requirements.
2. Meeting minimum admission requirements does not guarantee acceptance into a program.
3. Students will use technology regularly, including the Learning Management System (Brightspace), word processing software, presentation software, data/graphing software, and other programs/apps.
4. College or university credits can lead to course exemptions. More information can be found on the Transfer Guide page.
5. International students should refer to the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements.
6. First-year students in the C146 program must complete mandatory pre-placement health requirements and a Police Vulnerable Sector Check.
7. The pre-placement health requirements may take up to four months to complete, and all associated costs are the student's responsibility.
8. A Police Vulnerable Sector Check is necessary for students entering field or clinical placement and must be renewed annually.
9. The process of obtaining a Police Vulnerable Sector Check can take two to three months but may take up to eight months in some cases.
10. Students are responsible for ensuring their Police Vulnerable Sector Check covers appropriateness for working with vulnerable persons and must keep the original copy.
11. Students who cannot provide a clear Police Vulnerable Sector Check may not be able to start field or clinical placement, which could impact their program progress.

Context:
The text provides information about the requirements and application process for students in the George Brown College School of Health and Wellness programs. Here are some key factual extracts from the text:

1. Students who have a "not clear" status and fail to attend their practice placement may jeopardize their progress in the program and may not be able to complete it or secure employment.
2. Failure to meet requirements for field placement will prevent students from completing the program and securing employment.
3. Fees for police record checks vary and must be paid by students, and more information can be found on the pre-placement website.
4. Public Health recommends that students working with young children and other vulnerable communities be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 to complete field placements on time.
5. Domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, while international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.
6. Contact information for the George Brown School of Health and Wellness is available by calling 416-415-5000, ext. 2367 or emailing hwprograms@georgebrown.ca.
7. The text mentions some related programs offered at George Brown College, including Autism and Behavioural Science (Postgraduate), Honours Bachelor of Behaviour Analysis, and Practical Nursing.
8. Louis Busch is a behaviour therapist with the Centre for Addiction and Mental Health (CAMH) who uses behaviour analysis to help individuals with various disabilities and mental health issues. He has created and implemented a successful pilot program to increase staff capacity in community group homes. Busch also consults with CAMH's aboriginal outreach program.
9. Louis Busch holds an Ontario College Diploma.
